title: East Coast Types - No.4, The Scottish Fishwife
description: Poster, London and North Eastern Railway, East Coast Types, No 4, The Scottish Fishwife, by Frank Newbould, 1931.  Coloured lithograph depicting an elderly woman selling fish.  She is standing bent forward with a 'creel', a heavy wicker basket of fish on her back.  She wears a tartan shawl, blue duffel coat, blue and grey striped dress and sturdy boots.  In the background is a trawler.   The text is arranged around the woman's feet and inclludes the slogan "Travel cheaply by L.N.E.R.".  Artist's signature at top right.  Text at bottom margin reads "Published by the London & North Eastern Railway, Printed in England, Chorley & Pickersgill Ltd Lithographers Leeds".  Format: double royal. Dimensions: 40 x 25 inches, 1016 x 635mm.

Q9_Transcription: SURREY
Iron Railway.
The COMMITTEE of the SURREY
IRON RAILWAY COMPANY,
HEREBY, GIVE NOTICE, That the BASON at
Wandsworth, and the Railway therefrom up to Croydon
and Carshalton, is now open for the Use of the Public,
on Payment of the following Tolls, viz.
For all Coals entering into or going
out of their Bason at Wandsworth, } per Chaldron, 3d.
For all other Goods entering into
or going out of their Bason at } per Ton, 3d.
Wandsworth
For all GOODS carried on the said
RAILWAY, as follows, viz.
For Dung, - per Ton, per Mile, 1d.
For Lime, and all Manures, (except
Dung,) Lime-stone, Chalk, Clay,
Breeze, Ashes, Sand, Bricks, Stone, } per Ton, per Mile, 2d.
Flints, and Fuller's Earth,
For Coals, - per Chald. per Mile, 3d.
And, For all other Goods, - per Ton, per Mile, 3d.
By ORDER of the COMMITTEE,
W. B. LUTTLY,
Clerk of the Company.
Wandsworth, June 1, 1804.
BROOKE, PRINTER, No. 35, PATERNOSTER-ROW, LONDON.

Q9_Transcription: NEWCASTLE AND CARLISLE RAILWAY.
PLEASURE EXCURSION
TO
GILSLAND,
NAWORTH,
CORBY,
AND THE CITY OF
CARLISLE.
A SPECIAL TRAIN will leave the NEWCASTLE STATION on the Morning of
Wednesday the 19th August, 1846,
AT EIGHT O'CLOCK,
For the above Places, and will return the same Evening, leaving Carlisle at Five o'Clock.
The Directors have much pleasure in announcing that P. H. HOWARD, Esq. M.P. has kindly consented to allow
Parties by the above Train to have Free Access to his
Celebrated and highly Picturesque Grounds of
CORBY CASTLE.
FARES.
FIRST CLASS. SECOND CLASS. THIRD CLASS.
s. d. s. d. s. d.
Newcastle to Gilsland and back . . . . . . . . . . 8 0 6 0 3 6
Newcastle to Naworth and back . . . . . . . . . . 9 0 7 0 4 0
Newcastle to Corby and back . . . . . . . . . . 10 6 8 0 4 8
Newcastle to Carlisle and back . . . . . . . . . . 11 0 8 6 5 0
And from all the intermediate Stations to those Places in Proportion.
Passengers will be allowed to leave Newcastle by the Regular Train at Six o'Clock in the Morning, and return
by the Special Train at the same Fares.—By Order,
JOHN ADAMSON, Clerk to the Company.
Newcastle: Printed at the Journal Office, 19, Grey-Street, by John Hernaman.

Q9_Transcription: NORTH EASTERN RAILWAY.
NOTICE
OF
IMPENDING
STRIKE.
The Public are respectfully informed that in consequence of a certain number of the Company's Servants in New-castle, Gateshead, Sunderland, and the surrounding district, having given notice of their intention to cease work after Monday, the 22nd December instant, the Company cannot undertake responsibility for any delay in the carriage or delivery of Merchandise in the event of the occurrence of a strike.
H. TENNANT,
GENERAL MANAGER.
YORK, 16th December, 1890.
J. BELL & Co., Printers, Raway Lane, Pilgrim Street, Newcastle.

Q9_Transcription: D. 31,439.5M.
London, Brighton and South Coast Railway.
£25 REWARD.
WHEREAS, on the evening of
Wednesday, the 19th December,
1888, some evil-disposed person or
persons did wilfully and maliciously
place a piece of timber, about 4 feet
long by 1 foot thick, known as a
stop block, on the Up Line between
Ashtead and Epsom Town Stations,
thereby seriously endangering the
safety of the traffic.
The Directors hereby give notice
that the above Reward of Twenty-
five Pounds will be paid to anyone
who shall give such information
as will lead to the conviction of
the Offender or Offenders.
(By Order) A. SARLE,
London Bridge Terminus, Secretary & General Manager.
January, 1889.
(1,000) Waterloo & Sons Limited, Printers, London Wall, London.

EXCURSIONS

SCARBRO'
FILEY, AND

SPECIAL TRAINS WILL LEAVE THE
LANCASHIRE AND YORKSHIRE RAILWAY
EVERY SATURDAY,
Till further notice, beginning July 5th, AS FOLLOWS:—
TIME OF DEPARTURE
(from Stations mentioned below) FARE TILL AND BACK
FIRST CLASS. SECOND CLASS.
Manchester Vic'a St. Station ....... 1 30 ....... 7/
Oldham, Mumps (via Vic'a St.) ....... 1 30 ....... 7/
Ashton, M. St. (via Vic'a St.) ....... 1 40 ....... 7/
Rochdale (via Vic'a St.) ....... 1 50 ....... 7/
Bolton (from Bolton to Whitby, ...... 1 30 ....... 9/
Wigan (from Wigan to Whitby, ...... 1 20 ....... 9/
Preston (from Preston to Whitby, ...... 1 10 ....... 9/
DIRECTIONS FOR GOING.
Passengers for York, Whitby, Bridlington, Scarborough, Filey, and Harrogate, will proceed from
the Stations as above, as follows: —From Manchester Victoria Station, to Wakefield, (changing
there,) thence by the North-Eastern Railway; or, from Oldham, Mumps, Ashton, or Rochdale, via
Rochdale, (changing there,) thence to Wakefield, (changing there,) thence by the North-Eastern
Railway. From Bolton, Wigan, or Preston, via Wakefield, (changing there,) thence by the North-
Eastern Railway.
The First-Class Passengers by these Excursions will be entitled to remain 2, 3, 5, or 10 days, or on
Mondays from date of Ticket. The Second-Class Passengers to remain 2 or 3 days from date of Ticket.
The Tickets will be available for returning in 2 or 10 days on Mondays from date of Ticket, as follows:
For York (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
For Whitby (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
For Bridlington (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
For Scarborough (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
For Filey (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
For Harrogate (from Manchester) 115; (from Bolton) 115; (from Preston) 115.
On arriving at each place, Passengers must apply to the Station-master for information as to
the return trains.
NOTICE.—The Company are not responsible for delays, accidents, or loss of luggage.
Tickets and Bills at Stations, or J. STANLEY'S, 18, Victoria-d., Manchester.
1498-11572

Q9_Transcription: NORTH EASTERN RAILWAY.
REGULATIONS FOR TRAIN SIGNALLING by Block Telegraph System on Double Lines of Railway.
IN OPERATION FROM 1.0 P.M., SUNDAY, 1 th MARCH, 1896.

The object of the system of Block Telegraph Signalling is to prevent more than one train being in the Section between
Block Signalcabins on the same Line at the same time, and to keep following trains apart by an interval of not less
than one Clear Section or Block. The apparatus is constructed with this object in view, but the safety of the trains
depends largely upon the careful observance of the regulations. The Signal-cabins at which the Block Telegraph Working
is in operation, are furnished with Instruments to signal for each Line of rails, and the System under which the
apparatus works is described in the following Regulations. These must be strictly observed.
All Fixed Signals must be kept at DANGER, except when it is necessary to lower them for a train to pass, and before
any Signal is lowered, care must be taken to ascertain that the Line is clear, and that the Block Telegraph and other
Regulations have been carried out for the train.
When the Block Instruments are not in use the Indicators must be kept vertical; the indicators will then hang vertically,
and when in that position will indicate LINE BLOCKED, and this position of the Indicators must be regarded as
indicating LINE BLOCKED.
The movements on the Block Instruments and Bell must be made slowly and distinctly, and the pauses between the
sets of beats clearly marked.

1.—Call Attention. The Call attention signal must at once and in the first place precede every other signal, except where
it is stated that no Call attention signal is to be given. After the Call attention signal has been given, it must be
answered by the Signalman in the next Signal-box repeating it. If the Call attention signal is not answered, the
Signalman must not send the next signal, but must again give the Call attention signal, and if this be not then
answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
2.—Repetition and Acknowledgment of Signals.—Except where an acknowledgement is specially provided for by
these Regulations, every signal sent on the Block Telegraph Instruments must be at once repeated by the Signalman
to whom it is sent, and the Signalman sending it must acknowledge the signal by again giving it once, after which
it must be taken as correct, and if any Signalman should transmit an incorrect signal, he must immediately on discovering
his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the section.
3.—Mode of Signalling by Block Telegraph.—A. A Train having passed the Home Signal of an ordinary Signal-box, the
"Train entering Section" signal must be given to the Signalman in advance, and the "Train on Line" indicator put to
"Train on Line." As soon as the train has passed the Home Signal of the Signal-box in advance, the Signalman in
that Box must give the "Train out of Section" signal, and the "Line Clear" indicator put to "Line Clear." This
movement must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
4.—Line Clear, or giving Permission for a Train to Approach.—If an express passenger train is about to be sent
from one Signal Box to another, the Signalman must first ascertain that the Line is clear for the whole of the distance
between the two Boxes. The Signalman must then give the "Line clear" signal, which must be repeated by the
Signalman in the next Box. If the "Line clear" signal is not repeated, the Signalman must again give the "Line clear"
signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable
to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the
direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.

5.—At Junctions.—When, where advisable, the approach of trains can be observed by the Signalman in the next Box,
he must give the "Line clear" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.

When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
6.—Description of Trains.—When the "Line clear" signal has been given for an express passenger train, it must be
repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering
his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again
give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of
the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
7.—Train Entering Section.—The "Train entering Section" signal must be given when the train has arrived at the next
Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as
soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal. In no case must the
"Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of the Section.
8.—Train Out of Section.—The "Train out of Section" signal must be given when the train has arrived at the next
Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as
soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal. In no case must the
"Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
9.—Train Passed Without Tail Lamp.—The "Train passed without Tail Lamp" signal must be given when the train has
arrived at the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling
Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal.
10.—Ballast Train requiring to Stop in Section.—If a ballast train is required to stop in the section, the Signalman
must send the "Ballast Train requiring to stop in Section" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block
instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must
be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as
provided in Rule 77.
11.—Cattles, or other Train requiring to Stop in Section, or Platelavers' Lorry going
through to next Signal Box.—If a train carrying cattles, or other train requiring to stop in the section, or
a platelavers' lorry is required to pass through to the next Signal Box, the Signalman must send the "Cattles, or other
Train requiring to stop in Section, or Platelavers' Lorry going through to next Signal Box" signal, and if this be not
then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
12.—Obstruction danger signal to be given.—If an obstruction danger signal is required to be given, the Signalman must
send the "Obstruction danger signal to be given" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be
put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger,"
and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
13.—Fire, or Obstruction to be given.—If a fire, or obstruction is required to be given, the Signalman must send the
"Fire, or Obstruction to be given" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
14.—Stop and Examine Train.—If a train is required to be stopped and examined, the Signalman must send the "Stop
and Examine Train" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
15.—Caution.—If a caution is required to be given, the Signalman must send the "Caution" signal, and if this be not
then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
16.—Blocking Back for Passenger Trains.—If blocking back is required for passenger trains, the Signalman must send

Q1_Description: A historic railway poster from 1896 detailing regulations for train signalling using a block telegraph system on double lines. It features diagrams of bell and dial signals, along with extensive instructional text.

Q9_Transcription:
NORTH EASTERN RAILWAY.
REGULATIONS FOR TRAIN SIGNALLING by Block Telegraph System on Double Lines of Railway.
IN OPERATION FROM 1.0 P.M., SUNDAY, 1 th MARCH, 1896.

The object of the system of Block Telegraph Signalling is to prevent more than one train being in the Section between
Block Signalcabins on the same Line at the same time, and to keep following trains apart by an interval of not less
than one Clear Section or Block. The apparatus is constructed with this object in view, but the safety of the trains
depends largely upon the careful observance of the regulations. The Signal-cabins at which the Block Telegraph Working
is in operation, are furnished with Instruments to signal for each Line of rails, and the System under which the
apparatus works is described in the following Regulations. These must be strictly observed.
All Fixed Signals must be kept at DANGER, except when it is necessary to lower them for a train to pass, and before
any Signal is lowered, care must be taken to ascertain that the Line is clear, and that the Block Telegraph and other
Regulations have been carried out for the train.
When the Block Instruments are not in use the Indicators must be kept vertical; the indicators will then hang vertically,
and when in that position will indicate LINE BLOCKED, and this position of the Indicators must be regarded as
indicating LINE BLOCKED.
The movements on the Block Instruments and Bell must be made slowly and distinctly, and the pauses between the
sets of beats clearly marked.

1.—Call Attention. The Call attention signal must at once and in the first place precede every other signal, except where
it is stated that no Call attention signal is to be given. After the Call attention signal has been given, it must be
answered by the Signalman in the next Signal-box repeating it. If the Call attention signal is not answered, the
Signalman must not send the next signal, but must again give the Call attention signal, and if this be not then
answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
2.—Repetition and Acknowledgment of Signals.—Except where an acknowledgement is specially provided for by
these Regulations, every signal sent on the Block Telegraph Instruments must be at once repeated by the Signalman
to whom it is sent, and the Signalman sending it must acknowledge the signal by again giving it once, after which
it must be taken as correct, and if any Signalman should transmit an incorrect signal, he must immediately on discovering
his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the section.
3.—Mode of Signalling by Block Telegraph.—A. A Train having passed the Home Signal of an ordinary Signal-box, the
"Train entering Section" signal must be given to the Signalman in advance, and the "Train on Line" indicator put to
"Train on Line." As soon as the train has passed the Home Signal of the Signal-box in advance, the Signalman in
that Box must give the "Train out of Section" signal, and the "Line Clear" indicator put to "Line Clear." This
movement must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
4.—Line Clear, or giving Permission for a Train to Approach.—If an express passenger train is about to be sent
from one Signal Box to another, the Signalman must first ascertain that the Line is clear for the whole of the distance
between the two Boxes. The Signalman must then give the "Line clear" signal, which must be repeated by the
Signalman in the next Box. If the "Line clear" signal is not repeated, the Signalman must again give the "Line clear"
signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable
to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the
direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.

5.—At Junctions.—When, where advisable, the approach of trains can be observed by the Signalman in the next Box,
he must give the "Line clear" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.

When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
6.—Description of Trains.—When the "Line clear" signal has been given for an express passenger train, it must be
repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering
his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again
give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of
the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
7.—Train Entering Section.—The "Train entering Section" signal must be given when the train has arrived at the next
Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as
soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal. In no case must the
"Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of the Section.
8.—Train Out of Section.—The "Train out of Section" signal must be given when the train has arrived at the next
Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as
soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal. In no case must the
"Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually out of the Section.
When a train is sent from one station to another, the Line is said to be "Clear" when all the Signals are at "Danger,"
and the Line is clear for the whole of the distance between the two stations. When the "Line clear" signal is given,
it must be repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on
discovering his error give the Cancelling Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must
again give the correct signal. In no case must the "Train out of Section" signal be given until the train is actually
out of the Section.
9.—Train Passed Without Tail Lamp.—The "Train passed without Tail Lamp" signal must be given when the train has
arrived at the next Box, and if he requires to send a train, he must immediately on discovering his error give the Cancelling
Signal, and as soon as it is repeated by the Signalman in the next Box, he must again give the correct signal.
10.—Ballast Train requiring to Stop in Section.—If a ballast train is required to stop in the section, the Signalman
must send the "Ballast Train requiring to stop in Section" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block
instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must
be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as
provided in Rule 77.
11.—Cattles, or other Train requiring to Stop in Section, or Platelavers' Lorry going
through to next Signal Box.—If a train carrying cattles, or other train requiring to stop in the section, or
a platelavers' lorry is required to pass through to the next Signal Box, the Signalman must send the "Cattles, or other
Train requiring to stop in Section, or Platelavers' Lorry going through to next Signal Box" signal, and if this be not
then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
12.—Obstruction danger signal to be given.—If an obstruction danger signal is required to be given, the Signalman must
send the "Obstruction danger signal to be given" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be
put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger,"
and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
13.—Fire, or Obstruction to be given.—If a fire, or obstruction is required to be given, the Signalman must send the
"Fire, or Obstruction to be given" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
14.—Stop and Examine Train.—If a train is required to be stopped and examined, the Signalman must send the "Stop
and Examine Train" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
15.—Caution.—If a caution is required to be given, the Signalman must send the "Caution" signal, and if this be not
then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which
the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which
the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
16.—Blocking Back for Passenger Trains.—If blocking back is required for passenger trains, the Signalman must send
the "Blocking Back for Passenger Trains" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to
"Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and
steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
17.—Blocking Back except for Passenger Trains.—If blocking back is required except for passenger trains, the
Signalman must send the "Blocking Back except for Passenger Trains" signal, and if this be not then answered, the
Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required
must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as
provided in Rule 77.
18.—Line Clear after Blocking Back.—If line clear is required after blocking back, the Signalman must send the "Line
Clear after Blocking Back" signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked,"
and the Signals applicable to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for
protecting the Line in the direction from which the train is approaching, as provided in Rule 77.
19.—Cancelling Signal.—If a cancelling signal is required to be given, the Signalman must send the "Cancelling Signal"
signal, and if this be not then answered, the Block instruments must be put to "Line Blocked," and the Signals applicable
to the Line on which the attention is required must be kept at "Danger," and steps taken for protecting the Line in the

Q9_Transcription: Wear Valley RAILWAY. PLEASURE TRIP TO WOLSINGHAM AND FROSTERLEY. On Tuesday, August 31, 1847, A SPECIAL TRAIN WILL LEAVE A.M. Darlington - - at 8'0 Aycliffe - - - at 8'10 Shildon - - - at 8'30 Bishop-Auckland at 8'40 And return from FROSTERLEY at 4-30 p.m. FARES, THERE AND BACK: 1st Class, 2s. 6d.--2nd do., 2s. 0d.--3rd do., 1s. 6d. Parties will be highly gratified by a Trip up the delightful Valley of Weardale, and with a view of the wild and romantic scenery of Bishopley Craggs. The Town of Stanhope with its Castle, and Stanhope Burn with its numerous Lead Mines and its Iron and Lime Works, in addition to its attractive Scenery, will afford much pleasure to the Visitor. J. READMAN, PRINTER, DARLINGTON.

Q9_Transcription: No. 63. D. 2,765/85. London, Brighton and South Coast Railway. CAUTION. LIST OF CONVICTIONS. NAME. ADDRESS. NATURE OF OFFENCE. WHEN AND WHERE CASE HEARD. RESULT OF CONVICTION. HORACE PECKHAM. 6, Ropely Terrace, Brighton Road, Croydon. Having paid his fare for a certain distance, did knowingly and wilfully proceed beyond such distance without previously paying the additional fare for the same, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, May 14th, 1885. July 1st, 1885, Croydon Police Court. Fined Ten Shillings and Seven Shillings Costs. EVERILL, Mrs. Harcourt Lodge, Eldon Road, Croydon. Travelling in a carriage belonging to the Company without having previously paid her fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, May 15th, 1885. July 1st, 1885, Croydon Police Court. Fined Twenty Shillings and Thirteen Shillings Costs. WILLIAM RICHARD BIRD. 20, Albion Street, Brighton. Travelling on the Company's Line without having previously paid his fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, July 2nd, 1885. July 3rd, 1885, Belgate Police Court. Fined Forty Shillings and Fifteen Shillings Costs, or One Month's Imprisonment, with hard labour. JOHN CRAGGS. 92, Union Road, Clapham. Being a Passenger travelling in one of the Company's carriages, did unlawfully use a ticket not available on such day, viz.:—May 21st, 1885. July 8th, 1885, Southwark Police Court. Fined Five Shillings and Two Shillings Costs. LOBANDO JONES. 12, Nunhead Terrace, Nunhead. Throwing stones at passing trains, May 27th, 1885. July 8th, 1885, Greenwich Police Court. Fined Ten Shillings and Two Shillings Costs. W. STORY. 98, Minford Road, Shepherd's Bush. Using a ticket on a day for which such ticket was not available, May 9th, 1885. July 13th, 1885, Croydon Police Court. Fined Twenty Shillings and Thirteen Shillings Costs, or Seven Days' Imprisonment. ALBERT SIMPSON. 19, Carmichael Road, South Norwood. Travelling in a carriage belonging to the Company without having previously paid his fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, May 22nd, 1885. July 16th, 1885, Southwark Police Court. Fined Twenty Shillings and Two Shillings Costs. CHARLES JONES. 21, Webber Row, Blackfriars Road. Being drunk, using obscene language, obstructing the Company's Officers and interfering with the comfort of other passengers, July 20th, 1885. July 22nd, 1885, East Grinstead Police Court. Fined Forty Shillings and Twenty-four Shillings and Sixpence Costs, or One Month's Imprisonment with hard labour. WILLIAM COX. 24, Station Street, Lewes. Being drunk, refusing to quit the Company's premises, and assaulting one of their Servants in the execution of his duty, July 25th, 1885. July 27th, 1885, Brighton Police Court. Fined Ten Shillings and Ten Shillings Costs, or Fourteen Days' Imprisonment with hard labour. ELIZA HALL, EMILY JANE HALL. Leeds Farm, Five Ashes, Mayfield. Being Passengers in a certain carriage on the Company's Railway, and having paid their fare for a certain distance, did knowingly and wilfully proceed beyond such distance without previously paying the additional fares for the same, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, June 27th, 1885. July 29th, 1885, Hailsham Police Court. Each fined Twenty Shillings and Ten Shillings Costs, or Fourteen Days' Imprisonment. EDWARD ELDRIDGE. South Street, Worthing. Being drunk and disorderly on the Company's premises, August 3rd, 1885. August 4th, 1885, Steyning Police Court. Fined Twenty Shillings and Nine Shillings and Sixpence Costs. JAMES CORKERY. 5, Clarendon Street, Rotherhithe. Assaulting one of the Company's Servants in the execution of his duty, August 7th, 1885. August 7th, 1885, Thames Police Court. Fined Ten Shillings, or Seven Days' Imprisonment. JOHN SAUNDERS. Rudgwick. Travelling in a Carriage belonging to the Company without having previously paid his fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, May 30th, 1885. August 8th, 1885, Horsham Police Court. Fined Forty Shillings and Thirteen Shillings Costs. JOSEPH ANDREWS. 1, Czar Street, Deptford. Unlawfully travelling in a certain carriage belonging to the Company without having previously paid his fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, July 10th, 1885. August 12th, 1885, Greenwich Police Court. Fined Ten Shillings and Two Shillings Costs. OLIVER LEWIS MILLARD. 21, St. James' Road, Croydon. Travelling in a carriage belonging to the Company without having previously paid his fare, and with intent to avoid payment thereof, July 16th, 1885. August 12th, 1885, Southwark Police Court. Fined Forty Shillings and Two Shillings Costs. London Bridge Terminus, September, 1885. Waterlow and Sons Limited, Printers, London Wall, London.
